Well ... the whole universe is based on quantum mechanics, so it is a universe sized quantum computer, too.
You need to explicitly define what exactly you mean by "simulate the whole universe".

As I understand, it is essentially a one-time-pad. It has a significant disadvantage, that the key length should be at least the size of the cleartext, the key is not reusable, and that sharing the key requires a hidden channel. What about exp(exp(time)) problems?
@Fabian If you have an answer, please post it in the answer sections below. Thanks.

@jknappen I believe it can be combined to one question

@Rixwaan: No, there are cryptographic primitives that can be realised with quantum computers, but not with classical ones. And there are classical algorithms that cannot be cracked efficiently using a quantum computer. Two different thing.
@jknappen Oh ok, my lack of understanding, sorry

@peterh yes it is an one-time pad. The problems you described were meant to be summarized in the last paragraph. I am sorry, but I have nether heard about exp(exp(time)) problems? What is this? A short Google search can't help me. Could you please give me some keywords that will direct me to the right target and I will try to include it into my answer.

Possible duplicate of [Is it possible for an encryption method to exist which is impossible to crack, even using quantum computers?](https://quantumcomputing.stackexchange.com/questions/3/is-it-possible-for-an-encryption-method-to-exist-which-is-impossible-to-crack-e)

Classical devices can use typical random-number generators, or whatever's appropriate for their purposes. Randomness isn't a fundamental quality that needs to be sourced from quantum mechanics (which is a pretty big conceptual misunderstanding folks often get from the [Copenhagen interpretation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copenhagen_interpretation), which is perhaps best understood as a simplifying approximation).
I can think about [One-time pad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-time_pad)

I'm voting to close this question as off-topic because this question is about physics and better asked on [physics.se]. There is no *computation* involved.

Excellent. I'd love to see more such detailed answers on this site.
Sounds a lot like "The Machine Starts" by Greg Bear
I am open for improvement suggestions.
I think this question is wayyy too broad. You're asking 2 (albeit related) questions here. A better one would be "how do quantum computers differ from normal computers", or similar.
I am open for clarification requests.

Note that none of these emulators can (currently) be used by Q#, which only works with Microsoft's QDK.
@jknappen I think communication is a pretty important part of computation. Obviously, the distinction between what belongs here or on the Physics site will be an ongoing point of discussion here.
I've tried to make it more specific. I'll vote to reopen if those changes (and maybe some more) are made.
@Riker Done. Thank you for your consideration.
Still too broad in my opinion. The sub-questions can be easily be standalone questions.
I'm not clear what you're asking. Are you asking for an algorithm capable of solving things/generating more algorithms? That doesn't seem like a question about "quantum computing" to me.

@Riker Not about algorithm construction, it is about the construction of QM many-body systems (i.e. chemical formulas). Calculating the properties of a chemical compound is very hard with classical computers, the Schroedinger-equation is not a very easy thing even for a relative small degrees of freedom, but they can be solved easily by quantum computing. The essence of the question: What is the case, if we have the properties of the quantum many-body system, and we are looking for the system actually "implementing" it? Is it now understable? How to improve the question?
Your comment and your question are not easily understandable. I don't understand what you mean by "specification/implementation."

The problem with this question is that it reads more like a title to a seminar or a round-table discussion. Stack Exchange works a bit different than most discussion forums. Questions are generally expected to contain **a very specific problem statement** you might encounter in your day to day work or study — something that can be solved *definitively* in the space of a post. There's nothing inherently wrong with this discussion; it's just not a good fit for *this* type of Q&A site.

@Riker Well, I borrowed this terminology from the IT :-) In the software development, the specification is the description, what a program does. The implementation is the program what does it. Here I understand on "specification" the definition of the properties of the required system. And on "implementation" I understand the system which actually does it.
@Riker I tried to clarify the post, how does it look now?

I fail to see how this relates to quantum computing. I think you're just asking about supercomputers in general, which quantum computers may happen to solve. In my mnd, that's analogous to asking about how electricity works on SO.
@Riker I removed the offtopic terminology and tried to reformulate it as a 100% QC question. How does it look now?
I don't see the change really, but maybe somebody else will.
@Riker There is the difference in the sense, that the question now doesn't use offtopic terminology. There may be still the problem, that it is not easily understable. I am focusing now for that.
@Nat the question was about Turing machines, though, not about "classical devices"...
"_Classical devices_" includes Turing machines.
@Nat right, but not every classical device is a Turing machine
<comment-answers removed> If you have an answer, please post it in the answer section below. Thanks.
@JuanGonzálezSalinas that's a bit of a cheap answer though, since it's proven impossible (iirc).

Note: you're asking two distinct questions (hence my downvote): 1) "How does the quantum gate affect the result of **measuring** the state of the qubits?", 2) "Is it possible to know, in advance, how the probabilities of each state change due to the quantum gate?". They are quite distinct questions. I would ask them in different posts.

Note: matrices are not transformations, matrices **represent** transformations. You may have more than one matrix which represents a single transformation! My edit simply made your question more accurate. I will leave my downvote until you fix the "issues" regarding your question.

@nbro those aren't separate questions. the measurement yields a result, with some probability. Thus, transforming the state (i.e. a quantum gate) changes those probabilities, directly affecting the measurement.
@nbro better now?

I still think you're asking two distinct question, even though they are related. The last question "is it possible to know, in advance, how the probabilities of each state change due to the quantum gate?" (which is also in the title due to me), from a mathematical perspective, seems to be "how the matrix-vector product works" or, more generally, "how the tensor product" works.

Heather, I feel this might become a list question. Perhaps you could narrow it down? At this time, there probably is a small number of methods (maybe just one), but in the future there might be more, which would mean that more answers would be added...

@nbro but that's not what I'm asking. I know how to multiply matrices, thank you. It's the physics and theory that I'm interested in, rather than just the mathematical tools used to represent. I'll clarify by changing the first line

Whatever tasks/algorithms they were tested against.
You may specify that in your question. Even better, you may do a little research regarding the topic and include a few details in your question.
By a 'qubit grid', do you mean a [graph state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_state)?
I mean grid of qubits. Related study: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1712.01356.pdf
@DanielSank it is now enabled
What do you exactly mean by "in the sense of quantum mechanics"?

That article has some problems. This sentence, "48 qubit grid would require...double that of the top supercomputer" is closely followed by "Google will need to build a 49 qubit system... will deliver by end of the year"

Personally, I feel this would be a much better question if, instead of talking about 'computational performance' (which isn't well defined, although there are certainly numerous good possible questions in this area), you either just ask about speed of qubit initialisation, a single anneal, followed by a measurement or find a much more specific question about computational performance
I'm not an expert, but I thought the situation was that we don't know if that second claim is truly the case or not.

@tox123 The second point's necessarily true, though it'd be an open question under an inconsistent logic. It's kind of a weird situation in which an attempt at simplifying the concept invites tons of undue confusion.

Would you be able to explain what you mean by randomness just being ignorance? I'm very possibly looking at this the wrong way, but it does read to me like you're saying that everything is deterministic, which is purely an interpretational issue, so doesn't have any defined answer

@Mithrandir24601 Randomness being ignorance, i.e. representing stuff that we don't know how to predict, is the literal definition of the concept. The stuff about fundamental non-determinism is fundamentally unfalsifiable as potential complexity is unbound, such that we can never conclude that all possible modes of determination are false, such that we can never actually prove non-determinism. This makes it a non-concept. I think folks talk about it because it seems like a neat simplification, but it leads to all of this undue confusion over the nature of randomness.

Said another way, anyone who claims that the universe is fundamentally non-deterministic is claiming that they know for certain that no one will ever discover a way to predict certain things. Since they can't actually prove such a proposition, since it's literally impossible to somehow know that for sure, they'd be making an entirely meaningless claim, on-par with any other unfalsifiable dogma. Such dogma isn't in the realm of science or reason.

It doesn't make much sense to say that "*a quantum computers belong to X complexity class*". That's like saying "a (classical) computer belongs to the Y complexity class". A (quantum) computer is a device on which you run (quantum) algorithms, such algorithms *may* belong to a given computational class. You can just as well try and solve P or PP problems on a quantum computers. Also, quantum algorithms do not have to be probabilistic.

I would say that "true randomness" is *computationally equivalent* to ignorance. This is because, when you analyze the expected output of a randomized program, inserting a sampling step in the middle (to "resolve ignorance") does not change the distribution that the program is sampling from.

+1 I am not aware of any algorithm that returns a molecule with properties close to some input properties. However, I do think that this is indeed a very reasonable question in the context of quantum computation!
@CraigGidney Scientifically, the only thing we've ever observed about this is our own inability to make certain predictions; "_true randomness_" isn't a thing that's ever been observed.

@Nat There are ways to prove "true randomness" (no one could have known the outcome before we measured) under reasonable assumptions (e.g. no signaling) using Bell's theorem. It might be worth a question.

@M.Stern Honestly I think that Bell's theorem just confuses people more. I mean, don't get me wrong - it's a great test for local realism. But local realism is almost certainly false anyway; we're not testing it to see if it'll break so much as to see _how_ it'll break. Trying to pull "_true randomness_" as a conclusion from such a limited model is a circular argument.

@glS Fair points, so I've edited to fix/clarify this - the only thing is that non-probabilistic algorithms still have a bounded error, in that the failure rate is 0, so probabilistic is just a generalisation of deterministic

This question is pretty clearly relevant to quantum information technology. While not strictly speaking "computation", it is certainly part of what one might imagine a quantum computer would be used for. Having said that, the answer is pretty clearly "no, entanglement cannot be used for FTL communication" (and the OP should be edited to actually make use of the word 'entanglement' rather than 'quantum pairs').

In addition to what you said: There are programatic ways to run code on the IBM Quantum Experience which provides real quantum computers - not Q# code, but QASM instead. QISKit is the way to go here. https://github.com/QISKit
For a definition of realistic time: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P_versus_NP_problem
Specifically about weather modeling, you may be interested in the paper "Frolov, A.V. Russ. Meteorol. Hydrol. (2017) 42: 545. https://doi.org/10.3103/S1068373917090011"

I'm aware of P vs NP, yes. There is no proof, so far, that P != NP (though many computer scientists believe this to be true). So even if you could solve an NP hard problem in polynomial time on a quantum computer, would that prove quantum supremacy?
It depends. If you require the same algorithm it would be so, otherwise it doesn't have to be so

Do you have a reference for the theorem(?) you begin with? I think it would be helpful to see it in context, since at least for me it seems to be easy to misunderstand (seems odd to me for example that you can't simulate a large vacuum effectively). I'm not an expert on this!

I suspect that this question might be a tad too broad, I think even if we focus on just one specific realization of qubits a good answer would be long.
What is SPDC? Please explain.
@Kiro It's a common abbreviation for [Spontaneous parametric down-conversion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_parametric_down-conversion).

As a footnote: with respect to your question "Does it have to be the same algorithm?", a quantum computer can only achieve an advantage over a classical computer by using a *radically different* algorithm. The reason is simple: quantum computers would not achieve an advantage by performing operations *more quickly* (certainly not in their current state of development, and possibly not ever) but by performing *fewer* operations, which do not correspond to sensible operations that a conventional computer could be made to do.

So, just to make sure: With Googles announcement of the 72 qubit Bristlecone chip (https://research.googleblog.com/2018/03/a-preview-of-bristlecone-googles-new.html) and the largest number of qubits simulated to my knowledge being 56 qubits (https://arxiv.org/abs/1710.05867) we could reach that as soon as Google has proven their chip?

Provided that the qubits in the Google chip are stable enough, and the error rates in the operations low enough, that one could perform enough operations to do something which is difficult to simulate classically before the memory decoheres — then yes, that **could** be the first "quantum ascendancy" event. In principle, it makes a lot of sense to talk about the ascendancy of any given architecture, of which Google's Bristlecone is one example. But as a piece of historical trivia, it would be interesting to note who was first to the mark, and Google may end up being the first.

I'm also not entirely convinced by the premise of the question. Does Gil give a reason (or a particular architecture) for his claims to hold? Re-focusing this question to ask after what exactly Gil is claiming would be another way to go.
What do you mean by 1) "quantum resources" 2) "compute outputs from inputs" ?

@Blue By quantum resources, I mean anything that is inherently non-classical, like entanglement and coherence. By computing outputs from inputs, I mean a process which transforms the inputs (such as qubits) to outputs (results of the computation). If there is a more conventional or clear way to say these things, I would be happy to know.

@Mithrandir24601 I think this question (i.e. the question from the perspective I defined above) is perfectly fine. Even if we have thousands of techniques, we can add many answers, right? We can also have other questions requiring description and details regarding specific techniques. Why not?!

@NieldeBeaudrap Community wiki is no longer used for such purposes. Wiki should not be used to deny or remove reputation nor to justify questions which otherwise would not be allowed. [Future of Community Wiki](https://stackoverflow.blog/2011/08/19/the-future-of-community-wiki/)

@nbro: "How to reduce noise" is not a question of mathematics, but of trying things to see if they work well enough. On this site, we don't have the ability to try things to see if they work, so all we are left with is speculating about what things might work. --- Unless of course we interpret the question to be just "how does quantum error correction work", in which case its not a question of how to improve the existing technology, but rather why we expect that there is anything that we could possibly do.
@Kiro It will be better if you edit that into the question.

"On this site, we don't have the ability to try things to see if they work, so all we are left with is speculating about what things might work." But we have the ability to report the results of scientists and engineers (after having read and interpreted them).

@NieldeBeaudrap What I wanted to ask is that IBM, Rigetti and some other companies have already started manufacturing Quantum computers with 4-6 qubits. How have they overcome this problem of noise sensitivity of qubits is the question.
@SchrodingersCat I think you should add that to the question. Focused and detailed questions always receive better answers. Also link to paper you are talking about in the question.

@SchrodingersCat: I expect that Gil would claim that they *haven't* overcome this problem. His criticism is one against scalable quantum computation for arbitrarily large input sizes, not 'small' quantum systems.

@Kiro: in my opinion, the question was well-posed with the word 'models' rather than 'methods'. The added clarification Blue asked for is good, but from my point of view (and theorists like me) it was a clear question to start with, and a good one for this site.

I think there should be a clear distinction between "this question is on-topic", "this question is clear", and "this question is good". While I understand why people think this might belong to physics (because it sounds foundations-y), it is very obviously on-topic as an application of quantum information technology, which seems to be on-topic generally for this site. The question was also pretty clear to start with, albeit it benefitted from some editing. The only problem is that (with apologies to Christopher) it was not a good question, except to allow us to dispel a popular myth.
@NieldeBeaudrap His criticism states that the noise factor would prevent quantum supremacy, although small scale quantum systems may be feasible.

@NieldeBeaudrap I prefer "models" too, but I will need think for a bit before I start making any reverts. I guess "computational model" might be interpreted differently from what I intended it to be. I'll think about this.
Only "noise" isn't a good tag. Maybe use something like "error-correction-codes".

*If a quantum computer can do it, then a classical Turing machine could, too.* - This stops being true as soon as you relax a bit what you mean by a "quantum computer". If for example your computer is "delocalized" (that is, maybe one part of it is somewhere and another part somewhere else, which is totally conceivable) then you are able to do things that are straight out impossible within classical physics. Violating Bell's inequalities is the paradigmatic example of this, but also a great many tasks that are usually expressed in terms of "games" fall into this category.

[quantum-cryptography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_cryptography) and [post-quantum cryptography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-quantum_cryptography) are not the same thing. Quantum-cryptography creates cryptographic techniques using quantum effects, while post-quantum cryptography creates classical software algorithms resistant to quantum algorithms such as Shor's algorithm. This question is actually not a duplicate of the linked question.
Also, I think a brief mention of Church-Turing thesis and Extended Church-Turing thesis would be a worth addition to this answer.
Are you looking for implementations or papers detailing possible ones?
I'm interested in theoretical proofs / calculations of the threshold. Hints to research papers are greatly appreciated!

Quantum cryptography does not claim to be unbreakable. If any it's some people who claim this, probably to get attention or because they don't know what they are talking about. Concerning Quantum Key Distribution (which is the process of exchanging a joint secret key between Alice and Bob -> symmetric key cryptography) quantum cryptography can offer provable **protocol** security!

This means that nobody will be able to decrypt your sent messages if not intercepted at the time of sending (by a side-channel attack for example). This makes quantum cryptography secure against **any** future technology advances. But as you mentioned correctly nothing in this world is 100% secure (if you don't want to pay for security with your life).
@glS What sorts of computations would you say that a quantum computer can do that a classical Turing machine simply couldn't do?
@uitty400 I amended the conclusion as per your comment - thanks.

@Nat what I mean is that if you define a quantum computer as a kind of device that given a set of inputs computes a set of outputs using some physical substrate, then yes you can always simulate this on a classical device (even though one could argue that solving certain problems in certain regimes would require more than the age of the universe on any classical device, so that they could be considered classically unsolvable even in principle). [cont]

However if you talk more generally of "quantum devices" approaching general "problems", then you can also consider nonlocal games, some of which are not solvable at all with only classical probability (where solvable can here mean something like: win the game with more than X probability)

@glS Ah, okay, so you're not talking about something that'd prevent a classical Turing machine from simulating a quantum computer, but rather some practical scenarios in which a classical device simply couldn't perform a task?

This answer implicitly supports OP's incorrect belief that bra-ket notation is used primarily in quantum computation.

However, the OP is right in the sense that the $|0\rangle,|1\rangle$ notation (to denote basis states) is primarily used in quantum computation.
Nice article about One Time pad [here](https://www.hackthis.co.uk/articles/one-time-pad)

I'm not sure the fact that there is a continuum of states plays any role. Classical computation with bits would also have the same problems if our technology were less mature, and indeed it did suffer meaningfully from noise at various times in its development. In both the classical and quantum case, noise doesn't conveniently average away under normal circumstances

@NieldeBeaudrap It does play a big role. In classical computation you know that you'd have to deal only with two states, *beforehand*. Just consider an example: In classical computation if a signal of $5$ mV represents "high" (or $1$-state) while $0$ mV theoretically represents the "low" (or $0$-state), if your operation ended up with something like $0.5$ mV it would be automatically be rounded off to $0$ mV because it is much closer to $0$ mV than $5$ mV. But in case of qubits there are an infinite number of possible states and such rounding off doesn't work.

Of course you're not wrong when you say that even classical computation suffered from the problem of noise. There's a well established theory of classical error correcting codes too! However, the situation is much more dire in case of quantum computation due to the possibility of infinite number of states of existence of a single qubit.

The techniques used for quantum error correction does not involve the fact that the state-space is infinite in any way. The arguments you are making seem to be drawing an analogy between quantum computing and analog computing --- while there is a similarity, it would imply that quantum error correction would be *impossible* if it were a sound analogy. In contrast, the state-space of many qubits is also like a probability distribution on bit-strings, of which there is also a continuum; and yet just doing error correction on definite bit-strings suffices to suppress error.

@Mithrandir24601 Did you even look over the paper once or just blindly looked at the title? The question is not about IBM's 5 qubit processors, it's about how to make the qubits more stable towards noise factors. The stated papers mention the related mathematics. Please go through them once.

I've had a brief skim through the papers - the first thing is that they're talking about different types of noise. The reason that I'm VTC-ing is because making qubits more stable depends on both the type of qubit and the *cause* of the noise. If you want to know how to reduce noise caused by magnetic fields on dots (which aren't qubits), that could be an interesting question. If you want to know how to implement a unitary more accurately, that could also be very interesting. Same for wanting to know what causes e.g. decoherence in IBM's systems, but you need to specify what you want to know

I don't think this needs to be closed. It is a very general question yes, but it could be answered by outlining the general methodology to protects qubits from errors (basically what quantum error correction is at a general level). Althought if the question is to be interpreted in that sense I would remove the references to the papers. On the other hand if you want to directly refer to the papers I agree that the question should be made more specific.

1) There are several techniques used to reduce noise in quantum computations. You'd surely come across some if you care to search around the net, a bit. If you want to question to be re-opened you should make the question more focused, and explain why exactly a short-span googling, didn't give you the information you wanted. 2) At present this is a question to which an answer would either be an exhaustive list of noise suppressing techniques or a brief overview. You got to specify which you want. (Keep in mind that list-type questions aren't very encouraged here. See the discussion on Meta).

That said, other questions might be asked about more specific contexts.

@EllaRose The original post asks *"What do all of these brackets and vertical lines mean?"* It does not ask what the 0 and 1 mean.
@Blue I'm still lost on how "_noise_" might be a confusing word, even for beginners. The above use of it looks good to me.

@DanielSank If Stack Exchange sites were explicitly meant for domain experts then ~95% of the active user-base wouldn't be present. :P It's meant for everybody who is interested in the or is studying the subject, or is an academic/expert. And that is why you had seen the options: Just Curious/Beginner/Prosumer/Avid Enthusiast/Academic/Expert while committing to the Area 51 proposal.

I feel this answer does add some clarity to what the paper is trying to address. However, as stated by the paper, "perfect security can be established over a subset of computations even if not all of the qubits are unknown to the server." How can this be if certain variables are known to the server? I am trying to understand what makes-up these computations.

@DanielBurkhart An easy way to achieve perfect security even when the server knows some of the parts of a computation is to basically one-time-pad what it knows, then have the analog of the pad be part of what it doesn't know. Another strategy might be a [homomorphic construction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homomorphic_encryption). Though, I suppose that I'm not entirely clear on exactly what's being asked.
Those strategies actually answer my question. I was confused as to what they meant by generic structure.
@DanielBurkhart Awesome, I'll add a blurb about it then!

@Nat I didn't think you were being rethorical, I just forgot to answer :). Anyway, yes that is what I meant. @Nat: interesting. I'm vaguely aware that this may currently be the case for GPUs, and (in a context not involving active computation) RAID arrays are an obvious example as well. But could you describe other hardware platforms for which classical computation must rely on error correction during a computation?

Seems like errors are most frequently in networking contexts, followed by disk storage, followed by RAM. Networking protocols and disks routinely implement error-correction tricks. RAM's a mixed bag; server/workstation RAM tends to use error-correcting code (ECC), though consumer RAM often doesn't. Within CPU's, I'd imagine that they have more implementation-specific tactics, but those'd likely be manufacturer secrets. Error-rates in CPU's and GPU's become relevant at an observable level in a few cases, e.g. in overclocking and manufacturer core-locking decisions.

Actually kinda curious about CPU-type error-correction now.. I mean, the cache would seem prone to the same issues that normal RAM is (unless somehow buffered with more power or something?), which'd presumably be unacceptable in server/workstation contexts. But at the register-level? That'd be something neat to read about; didn't see anything immediately on Google, though I suppose that such info'd likely be a trade secret.

@heather That looks like a dilution refrigerator to me. Those enormous copper braids are some kind of mechanical isolators. I think they're copper to keep the chassis of the cryostat all at the same voltage and avoid ground currents. The sliver windy wire looking thingy in the center is actually a pipe full of helium-4 and helium-3 mixture. The center pipe around which it's wrapped is the cold part of a compressor that gets to ~3 Kelvin. The thinner pipe is wrapped around to pre-cool the helium mixture as it makes it's way toward the mixing chamber where it gets to 10 mK.

@Kiro Measurement can also be thought of as a linear transformation, where state vectors in a higher dimensional complex vector space are mapped to state vectors in a lower dimensional complex vector space (which depends on the basis in which you're measuring).
More importantly, the linear transformation wouldn't be injective in such a case. So you can't reconstruct the initial state vectors. *That* makes it irreversible.

`If the two parties share a secure key, then the communication channel is unconditionally secure` - This is not true; If you use the key to encrypt your messages using AES (as QKD providers such as IDQuantique [admit to doing for practicality reasons](https://tinyurl.com/ybykklew)), then it is not unconditionally secure by any means. Using AES (or any cipher other than the OTP) with a secret key is *not* [information-theoretically secure](https://tinyurl.com/kov95la), regardless of how that key was derived.

@M.Stern In theory, if you had such a proof, then it would kill even the tiniest grain of legitimate motivation for QKD. On the one talon, it's unlikely that we will ever have such a proof, which we've never had for classical cryptanalysis. On the other talon, classical cryptography, including classical post-quantum cryptography, is available _right now_ to you and me to provide real defenses against real threats, and you're using it to post to this site—conceivably even [trials of post-quantum cryptography](https://www.imperialviolet.org/2016/11/28/cecpq1.html). QKD does nothing of the sort.

@M.Stern The tiniest grain of legitimate motivation for QKD also applies only to _online key agreement_, as in what a web browser negotiates with a web server. There are many other applications of classical cryptography, such as encrypted remote backup, that can be designed so they are no more vulnerable to quantum cryptanalysis than the conversations made with keys agreed upon with QKD—there's no serious quantum threat to pretty much any classical symmetric-key cryptography, as all commercial QKD systems use ot encrypt actual messages, only to certain public-key cryptosystems.

@Discretelizard When your web browser negotiates with the web server at quantumcomputing.stackexchange.com, it transmits over the internet the value of $2^a \bmod p$ where $p$ is a large prime satisfying certain criteria and $a$ is a 256-bit secret known only to the client, and receives $2^b \bmod p$ where $b$ is a secret known only to the server. You both compute $k = H(2^{ab} \bmod p)$ for some random function $H$ as your session key, and erase it when done. Conceivably, in the future, an eavesdropper could recover $a$ from $2^a \bmod p$ and from that derive the secret session key $k$.

@Discretelizard ([More detail](https://crypto.stackexchange.com/a/54087/49826) about this idealization. In reality, your browser will probably use elliptic-curve DH key agreement instead, but the principle is the same.) In contrast, the theoretical conceit of QKD is that the information that goes into making the key agreement—in a sense, the analogue of the $2^a \bmod p$ value—is transmitted in qubits, which the no-cloning theorem prevents an eavesdropper from simply duplicating. But the devil is in the details! There's far more to it than just trading qubits—including classical crypto.
@glS Ah, good point; that sentence does sound a bit odd out-of-context.

I mean, the security of quantum encryption is based in the idea that we somehow get a 'secure channel' without 'prior exchange', akin to hiring couriers with suitcases. Just as couriers can be bribed, suitcases forged and everyone deceived, can we 'bribe' the couriers of the 'quantum channel'?

@Discretelizard You're not missing anything. The module that _handles_ the key, _e.g._ to compute AES-GCM under that key to encrypt and authenticate a _conversation_, once QKD has chosen the key, could send it to GCHQ in a neatly wrapped envelope. And yes, QKD does not address _authenticating_ the key that you negotiate over a quantum channel. It only addresses _choosing_ the key. Then you use classical cryptography with pre-shared public keys, or a shorter pre-shared secret, to authenticate it, so you can detect a MITM who has spliced into your fiber link with their own QKD endpoints.

@M.Stern Right now, each _instance_ of a commercial QKD system is so expensive they don't have prices listed: you have to ask. (Hazy memory: hundreds of thousands of euros apiece, though no doubt a large part is taken by the marketing department.) That's for a physical box at each end of the _link layer_, connected by a single fiber optic cable or similar—not routed through arbitrary hops on the internet. Public-key key agreement works today, for zero cost in hardware, over _any medium you want_, including [IP over avian carriers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IP_over_Avian_Carriers).

@M.Stern Suppose the physics advanced so far that the cost reduced by a factor of millions and you could fit them into every smartphone in everyone's pocket, every industrial microcontroller on the planet, _etc._, as cheaply as Ethernet, USB, CAN, or what-have-you. Now, using QKD, you can negotiate a secret key shared with…your ISP. It still doesn't help you to negotiate a secret key shared with a _peer_ routed over the internet. If you want _end-to-end_ authenticated encryption where you can erase session keys beyond your ISP's control, you still need classical public-key key agreement.

In the last formula, did you mean ¼ four times, or is it indeed ½?

It's actually $|1/2|^2+|1/2|^2=1/2$. Out of the four terms in $\frac{1}{2}|00\rangle + \frac{1}{2}|01\rangle + \frac{1}{2}|10\rangle + \frac{1}{2}|11\rangle$, two of them have a $0$ in the first bit-position. So you add the probabilities of those two. Remember that probability of a basis vector $|ab\rangle$ occurring, when measured, is the square of its amplitude. @bytebuster

@Discretelizard I would hardly characterize a hundred-million speedup "meager". Complexity theory is way too obsessed with infinite size scaling limits. What matters in real life is how fast you get the answer to your problem.

@DanielSank Please excuse me for being a theorist, then :) . There are good reasons why CS theorists almost ignore constant speedups when dealing with algorithms on classical computers. (One is 'dividing the work'. Dealing with constants is the job of an 'algorithm engineer' (also a scientist!)) But perhaps there are good reasons to use different evaluations for QC. I think this leads to a question!
I've considered asking for more concrete comparison methods than 'constants vs no constants', but I think this is already non-trivial (controversial?), so let's see what will happen here first.

Ignoring constants isn't even always a good idea in classical computing. How is this a quantum computing question and not a question about how to think about algorithm resource scaling? In other words, when talking about the time or other resources needed to run a computation, whether the computation is quantum or classical seems irrelevant to the question of whether or not you care about a factor of a hundred million speed-up.

@DanielSank As I mentioned, ignoring constants in algorithm analysis has worked rather well for classical computing. It is also the de-facto standard for _algorithms researchers_. I'm quite interested in hearing about all those _algorithms researchers_ who apparently disagree. The main reason I'm asking this question is that 'ignoring constants' is a more of a rule than not for almost any algorithms researcher. As I'm sure this site will have such people as useful contributors, it might be interesting to know if such thinking should be adjusted when comparing QC with Classical C.

Hence, I think this is a question on Quantum Computing and not merely on computing. Feel free to expand on why you might think this is _still_ 'merely' a computing question (if you still do). I think I'll wait how the rest of the community reacts.
An interesting chat about this question is [here](https://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/43479144#43479144).

@SqueamishOssifrage Exactly. I'd like to add that equating membership of $P$ with 'efficient' is more wishful thinking by computer scientists than absolute truth. The idea is that, once it has shown that a problem lies in $P$, even if its something ghastly like $O(n^{1235436546})$, there will be improvements shaving it off to something similar to $O(n^3)$, a bit closer to the cosy 'conditional lower bounds'. To credit, this has usually happened in the past. But this is no guarantee and as for the practicality there even exist 'linear' algorithms that are considered 'unimplementable'.
It's already explained [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computing). Basically, with _x_ amount of qubits, you can have 2^x different values **at the same time**.

@Discretelizard: I am in favour of not throwing away the constants, in situations where the constants make a practical difference. But it is also true that 1e8 matters more in comparisons between quantum and classical technologies as they stand today, than it matters within classical computation.

> "Is it possible for an encryption method to exist which is impossible to crack, ..." - What constitutes "impossible", mathematical proof that it is not possible? What if it was *proven* that with computers advancing at the fastest rate possible that it could be broken in 10K years; is that "impossible" enough? - In the early days most *unbreakable* codes fell pretty quickly, it's only in the past few decades that people have known to test more and brag less. Not a criticism of your question, just a little more research and exactness. What if every 2nd word could be decrypted, is it broke?

@Rob It is a practical and not a theoretical impossibility. If the chance of the successful attack is $10^{-100}$ in the following $10^{100}$ years, then it is practically undecryptable (because the practical chance of a security breach in the same timescale is far bigger). The important thing is that the needed resources for a successful breach should be proven exponentially grow with the resource need of the key generation and encryption. (Btw: the currently applied technologies in the pre-quantum computing *lack* this theoretical proof)

When expressing classical computations in terms of logical operations, one makes use of gates. In some sense, these are essentially black boxes, whose inner workings are not often dealt with while studying classical algorithms. However, that is not how nature works: states evolve in a continuous fashion describable by differential equations. When talking about classical algorithms, one neglects the dynamic realising said evolution, which is how the gates are actually realised in physical systems. But the dynamic generating a gate is unimportant, so long as the gate can in fact be realised.

@NieldeBeaudrap I'm not sure whether you are rephrasing the question or asking something. Anyway, the dynamic generating a gate *is* important as soon as you need to actually implement the gate, it is just not directly dealt with when writing algorithms (though it is still considered, which is why most algorithms are expressed in terms of gates whose decomposition in terms of elementary gates are manageable). You don't need to worry about this in the classical case because we know very well how to make complex operations out of easy ones, but this is not the case with current quantum devices
I’ve occasionally heard of time travel as well but I suppose that would be the same as superluninal communication.

I'm making a rhetorical point: that the same argument could be directed at classical computation, but we allow ourselves the luxury of abstraction there because we know that the operations are realisable in principle, by a suitable application of manufacture and control. The only question is what level of 'principle' would satisfy you. Think about the analogy to the classical case: if you didn't know about consumer electronics, what level of detail would you hope for to be satisfied that NAND is physically realisable, rather than just as an intellectual abstraction for reasoning?

@NieldeBeaudrap the kind of answer I expect is something highlighting that the way more complex gates (say, Toffoli gates) are implemented is through 1) gate decomposition using sets of gates which are "simple" in a given architecture (which brings the highly nontrivial problem of quantum compilation), 2) quantum control techniques, 3) using ancillary degrees of freedom, 4) implementing the gate as an effective dynamics in a larger Hilbert space, 5) possibly other methods

So, you want to know how to decompose e.g. a Toffoli gate, but in some architecture, with an account of how the whole architecture works? Analogous to a description of how one realises NAND in terms of semiconductor physics, except for the more immature technological setting of quantum computation, where we are pretty sure that we have not yet completely solved the problem of scaling in any of our candidate technologies? I'm not sure your question will have an answer yet; and once it does have an answer, it will represent at least half of a semester course in engineering.

No, I'm asking about the methodologies used today to implement gates, which are more or less the ones I mentioned above. This is different than asking about how gates are decomposed in terms of easier (in a given architecture) gates, because that is just one way to do this. I edited the question trying to make this point clearer. Here is an example of a paper using one such technique to implement a Toffoli: https://arxiv.org/abs/1501.04676, which might enlighten as to the kind of answer this question may have

Interesting. Although I have one remark. "As for "big" data, it's just a matter of how much memory you have.", This, I think, is a bit _naive_. Be aware that when dealing with $10^5$ TB LIDAR data, (i.e., elevation data for every _square meter in whole Europa_ (that's about a square big footstep for you non-metric folks))), your data doesn't fit into memory, _no way_!

There is an entire _sub-field of algorithmics_ (known as I/O or cache-aware algorithms, of which some experts are at my uni ) that says, wait the common RAM (random access machine, i.e. 'we can get data everywhere in $O(1)$') model doesn't help us here, I/O-latency is what dominates the actual running time, we have to be 'cache aware'. So, I think your final remark is a bit too naive. But feel free to expand on it!

"Fortunately, quantum teleportation does not enable faster than light communication, because to complete the teleportation Alice must transmit her measurement result to Bob over a classical communications channel. ", so basically, we can't beat light speed because measuring quantum states is hard and requires them to share information from classical channels, correct?

Not quite. Bob can measure his qubit easily. But to discern the wave function that Alice wants to send from the potential states Bob will get from his measurement, he needs that extra classical information from Alice.
Ah, I see. The information from the measurement is too 'little' (i.e. insufficient) to have certain communication, is that a better interpretation?
More like not useful. He can't learn anything without knowing what state Alice's qubit is in.

'Destroying all bad universes' sounds very much like postselection to me
@Mithrandir24601 Could you elaborate?

Essentially, here, postselection means that you make a measurement and ignore all values that didn't give a specific outcome - you have an ancilla qubit, with a non-zero probability of being measured to be in state 1 and you condition the outcome on this result occurring (the point is that you ignore the time that it takes for the measurement outcome to be '1')

@Mithrandir24601 Okay, but how is that related to detecting whether in a certain universe, a list is sorted or not? Are you saying that detection is like making a measurement on a qubit, first and then detecting its state?
It's not necessarily 'the same', but it rings of the same principle, where you ignore the results that you don't want, as well as the time taken to get to them

Nice overview! I'll wait a bit for others before I'll accept, but this is already more than I wished for! One remark though, to be sure, the lower bound for comparison based sorting still holds on QC as we are only counting the number of comparisons (and we must spend $O(1)$ for each comparison in comparison based sort). Oh and btw, one 'practical usage' of bogosort is to run a normal (recursive, like mergesort or quicksort) sorting algorithm, but try the bogosort first and do your _actual sort_ on _failure_ (i.e. most of the time). This yields a not unpractical algorithm that is 'fun' to analyse!

I'm not sure if AI and QC blend nicely. On the one hand, quantum data storage is very much in its infancy. On the other hand, AI is satisfied with imprecise answers, so we likely need less error correction.

@M.Stern I guess the question is a bit more subtle than I thought. Of course if you allow nonlocal interactions, then you can get the desired correlations.
If you have an n qubit system and a circuit of depth less than log n, then indeed you can only implement local measurements. This means that if one model has a larger set of correlations than another, there are some small-depth measurements in the larger model that require much more depth to simulate in the smaller model. See e.g. https://arxiv.org/abs/1704.00690 for such a separation between quantum computers and classical computers.

@Discretelizard There are certainly analog aspects to quantum computation. But there are digital aspects too. Wave-particle duality essentially looks like analog-digital duality when looked at from a computational perspective.

As for your aside, you're correct - I'm just being a lazy physicist. It *is* (to my knowledge) a Haar measure, but calling it a 'Haar measure over states' is, yes, not exactly the most technically accurate statement ever... What's slightly more worrying is that arXiv currently seems to be down :(

@M.Stern well almost. If $U$ contains a $C(X)$ (which more precisely would be a $C(X)_{ij}$, acting between $i$-th and $j$-th qubit, with $i, j>1$), then the equivalent gate in $C(U)$ is *already* a Toffoli gate, with first and $i$-th qubits as control and $j$-th qubit as target. You can therefore go and replace the Toffolis using the known decompositions

I think to say "I think it's important, first, to point out that no one is 100% sure that a quantum computer is even actually better than a classical computer" is not correct since we have already quantum algorithms that are much better than classical ones. So, if one can build a quantum computer able to run these algorithms we can see that quantum computers are better than classical ones. Another thing is to say that the quantum computer can take some "metric of time" to run these algorithms.

@GustavoBanegas We have quantum algorithms that are better than the *best known* classical algorithms, but we don't have proofs that the quantum algorithms are better than *any possible* classical algorithm. (Well, we do in settings like query complexity and communication complexity, but not for decision problems or sampling problems.)

The second paragraph is touching the right points, but it is still very qualitative. You are saying that you need the gates introduced by the error correction protocol to reduce the error rate more than they increase it. However, how does one go from this intuitive idea to an actual quantitative estimate over the threshold? Also, does this imply an universal lower threshold that no error correcting protocol can beat?
@Discretelizard could you maybe edit to clarify your question then?
@heather I just did. What is still unclear?

@glS I suspect that there is such a "universal lower threshold", i.e. an error value above which there exist no fault tolerant correction protocols. However, the value should depend on both your gate set and your error model. People tend to be more interested in positive results here (showing the existence of a good fault tolerant protocol). It may be interesting to find upper bounds in order to see "how much room we have left" in making our fault tolerant schemes better. I'd guess there isn't much room left.

@DanielSank My understanding is that even the 100-million times speedup is possibly illusory, because it just shows that a multibillion dollar machine manned by a professional staff of 20 and optimized for over a decade can operate 100 million times faster than a naive classical algorithm for the same *broad class* of problem. I think that every time people have put serious work into optimizing the classical algorithm, to make a more "apples-to-apples" comparison, the time gap has closed.

The claim that the state vector of a system contains the "complete information" about the system is only true under certain interpretations of quantum mechanics (e.g. it is false in de Broglie-Bohm theory). In any case it's a bit misleading - you certainly can't predict the result of arbitrary measurements, which is how I would interpret "complete information".

This answer is incorrect and highly misleading. Shor's algorithm is *not* believed to be able to solve any NP-complete problems. Neither factoring nor discrete logarithms is believed to be NP-complete. This is a persistent misconception in popular accounts.

They need to use different algorithms. Right now most are based on elliptical curves with bad settings, bad curves, and extremely low key sizes. Blockchain represents very delicious, low hanging fruit to an attacker. sec256k1 in Bitcoin (and variants), Ethereum, etc needs to be replaced but that breaks the address system and wallet architecture.

Cardano does not appear to be quantum safe with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curve25519 from https://whycardano.com/#signatures Please note that a "secure signature" is only as secure as the private key that calculated it, so having BLISS on top of a quantum insecure public key is irrelevant. They need to replace the public-private key system to be quantum safe. Every transaction will reveal the private key, and an attacker can sign the transaction after recovering the key. Following Moore's Law for qubits and no piggyback engineering, Cardano is dead in April 2020.

I'm not convinced Grover's algorithm is relevant here. Grover's algorithm finds _the one unique input_ that exactly produces a given output. OTOH, neural networks are very much nonunique by nature, and they aren't really exact either – at best asymptically accurate.
Is there a way to represent it in circuits or operator matrices or some other more concrete form? I am a little confused as to how you make it access a specific input.

As the input is classical information (bits rather than qubits, just encoded as qubits), one can simply "copy" them with CNOTs. That's not a true copy but an entangled one, but that is good enough for this. It is important to uncompute the copy (again with CNOTs) or else Grover's algorithm won't work.

You say that |0>+|1> is a pure state. Are there no mixed superpositions? I think I understand the difference between pure and mixed, I'm asking how superpositions fit into this.

@Discretelizard According to the question, the OP (welcome to quantum computing SE by the way!) is looking for a quantum algorithm for simulating a physical system, which isn't the same as looking for something that can emulate a qc

@Norrius "mixture" and "superposition" are two separate concepts. A mixed state is always given by a *mixture* of different states. Indeed, a mixed state is *defined* as a convex sum (mixture) of other states. If a mixed state cannot be written as (convex) sum of other (pure) states, than it is not a mixed state but a pure state. Finally, a *superposition* of *pure* states is always, by definition, a *pure* state
Okay. Can you take a superposition of mixed states? Is that a meaningful operation?
@AndrewO I just edited the question along the same lines. Do you find it more appropriate now?
@whurley Yeah I think it's ok now.

@Norrius no it is not. Note that you cannot "take superpositions" of different states in practice. You can *evolve* a certain state into another state which can be described as a superposition of certain states. You can apply the same evolution to a *mixed* state, and what you will get is a mixture of two states, each one of which is described as a superposition in a given basis. This will still be a mixed state though.

tparker, I am very interested in your review of the papers I cited that support my claim of NP-completeness. If the papers are incorrect or I am misinterpreting them completely, then it changes my opinion on what the next 20 years of computing looks like.

You are misinterpreting them completely. Neither of these papers claims that factoring or discrete log are NP-complete. The first one specifically says that the possibility that "either [discrete log] or [factoring] is complete for NP ... is believed to be an unlikely event." It says that they *reduce* to an NP-complete set, which is a completely different statement and true by definition for any problem in NP. I don't see anything in the second paper that you could have possibly construed as a claim that factoring or discrete log are NP-complete.

I would argue that this is a bit too broad as asked. Perhaps something more like "why is entanglement needed for quantum error correction", and have a separate question for the classical analogy.

Having or not having entanglement does not affect quantum error correction. Yes, there are quantum systems without entanglements; the state such a system is in is called a product state because it can be written as (state of first qubit) $\otimes$ (state of second qubit), etc.
I edited down to one question, then realised that it would bias towards my answer over that of pyramids. But @Chinni, I agree with James that you should focus on one of the two questions.

@pyramids: I think that the statement "there is no classical equivalent to entanglement' is (while common to say) a slightly strong statement. There is a classical *analogue*, though it is in no way deeply mysterious. We invoke it every time we explain what entanglement is --- and then boldly claim "entanglement has no classical analogue" in order to keep people from confusing entanglement with that same classical analogue. But in the context of error correction, the role of that classical analogue is precisely what is at issue, because it is what makes *classical* error correction work.
@NieldeBeaudrap The way I understand entanglement (a non-product state), this statement is precise rather than excessively strong.

A pair of correlated classical random variables is also a non-product state, and it is precisely in this way that it is a classical analogue to entanglement. What makes your statement "strong" is that there is a freedom of choice in where one draws the line, between 'analogous' rather than 'non-analogous' phenomena, and you happen to have drawn the line at a high threshold (as is conventional to do with entanglement, for historical reasons).

@NieldeBeaudrap that is true for correlated variables, yes. But let's consider particles and states: Wouldn't it be possible to represent every system of classical particles as a product state of these particles? In this sense, I'd say there simply is no classical equivalence even if you can give correlated fluctuations as a classical analogue.

thanks for this answer, but I have two more question: how exactly is the ion shielded from radiation/light? and am I understanding wikipedia correctly and an ion trap is using electro-magnetic fields to "fix" the qubit in one position (not state)?

@MEE I tried editing the answer, but I just don't know how since it seems so trivial: Shielding something from light simply means to keep it in the dark (at least with regard to certain laser light needed to implement quantum gates: just block their light with a shutter). Yes, you understand wikipedia correctly, except that for quantum computing, usually quadrupole ion traps are used, so it's all solely due to electric, not magnetic fields. They do indeed maintain the position of the ion (by interacting with it) and, in a way, also its state (by leaving it alone, i.e. not interacting with it).
so basically we have a big (maybe 20cm) beton wall (to shield from radiation and light) and inside this are the ions trapped by an electric field? ok thanks.

It's much simpler: For blocking the *relevant* radiation (typically visible and possibly ultraviolet or infrared light), even a bit of paper would suffice. You still have a lot more than that because you also want to keep molecules of air from interacting with the ions, so you need a ultra-high vacuum chamber which is made from walls of maybe 2 cm thick steel or aluminium.

The positions of classical particles are just one type of thing that random variables can express. You can only represent the positions of classical particles by product states if you remove any element of randomness or indeterminacy from the description of the states of the classical particles. Doing so prevents the notion of correlation from applying as well, so this cannot be used to show that correlation is not a classical analogue of entanglement.

@NorbertSchuch The same dupe target again?

You ask *"when, given set of constraints on the allowed Hamiltonian parameters, a given target gate can be realized?"*. This has nothing to do with (quantum) (optimal) control. It is a property of the Hamiltonian. Quantum control is concerned with asking "how can I do this well/best". It's not about the "if", it's about the "how". The "if"-question is more fundamental, and I don't see how quantum control can address this (at least better than any other approach to universality, such as constructing a universal gate set).

@NorbertSchuch to be clear, are you saying that quantum control theory simply does not provide tools to answer this kind of question, or that the question itself is ill-posed? Also, isn't an "approach to universality" by constructing a universal gate set a completely different matter, being based on gate decomposition? Finally, when I talk of "universality", or "if-questions" if you like, I'm referring to things like the result given in 2.1 [here](https://arxiv.org/abs/0707.1883). Isn't this an example of such an "if-question" answered?

That result doesn't sound very deep. The question is indeed: How to you check the dimension of the Lie algebra. I'm sure there are some results also in control theory on that, but your question really doesn't have to do much with control theory. It's about knowing when families of Hamiltonians are universal. Any proof technique should be fine.

@Discretelizard: I am claiming something a bit subtler: the convention is an accident, because the computer scientist is more concerned with expediency for other purposes than with mathematical symmetry. The physicist and the mathematician both care about symmetries more than the computer scientist does, so what we've ended up with something that looks a little arbitrary. The specific arbitrary thing we've ended up with was itself steered by biases from computer science, but superficial biases rather than meaningful ones.

@Discretelizard: I do not know enough about 'quantum annealing' to address this question, but I can address it for the purposes of the adiabatic algorithm. If we could somehow magically dispel all sources of noise for very large adiabatic computers, then they could simulate unitary circuits in polynomial time. They are therefore universal in the usual sense. (I have seen it claimed that adiabatic computation is a limiting case of quantum annealing, in which case the same holds true for quantum annealing.) The question really isn't one of computational models, but of practical engineering.

Indeed, before the arrival of computer scientists, the physicists' preferred maximally entangled state was the singlet state, a.k.a. $|\Psi^-\rangle$. See e.g. all the 20th century papers about Bell's inequalities.
But it was said, that when one atom is stopped, the other one also stops. Could Bob observe when his atom stops, and this way get information, that Alice stopped her atom?

@Staszek I think you're asking if there is a way for Bob to determine if Alice has measured her qubit. The answer is no. Bob will measure his qubit and receive one of the four possible states. Bob doesn't know if Alice has measured hers or what her measurement was unless Alices tells Bob classically what her measurement was so he can 'decode' his state to learn the wave function that Alice wanted to teleport.

@IanSmith It seems you're missing some knowledge on complexity theory. I'd suggest reading these questions on [the difference between algorithms and problems](https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/13669/what-is-the-difference-between-an-algorithm-a-language-and-a-problem) and on [P, NP, NP-completeness and NP-hardness](https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/9556/what-is-the-definition-of-p-np-np-complete-and-np-hard). Also note that complexity theory isn't merely only of interest to scholars. At least a few results from complexity are directly relevant in software engineering.
In general if you don't care about efficiency, you can just try every element of a space instead of sampling from it, avoiding the need for randomness.

Again, it makes no sense to talk about "algorithms that have a lower computational complexity than NP". NP measures the complexity of problems, not of algorithms. If you mean the discovery of a *polynomial-time* algorithm that solves NP-complete problems, then I'd call that a proof that P = NP. Such an algorithm would win you a Millennium Prize and $1 million, but I wouldn't recommend searching for one as a retirement investment strategy.
I would prefer you quote my entire sentence, or at least capture the subject as referenced. "When the NP-complete problems get solved ... [using]... lower computational [time]... than NP."

Thanks --- I hope that we might be able to pin down some additional details though. **(1)** I saw your previous answer, but don't get the point you make here. It's fine for QA not to be universal, and not to have provable performance to solve a problem, and for these to be motivated by hardware constraints; but surely quantum annealing is *something* independent of specific hardware or instances, or else it doesn't make sense to give it a name. (cont'd)

**(2)** Your linking the AQC paper, together with the excerpt by Vinci and Lidar, strongly suggests that QA is just adiabatic-ish evolution in the not-necessarily-adiabatic regime. Is that essentially correct? Is this true regardless of what the initial and final Hamiltonians are, or what path you trace through Hamiltonian-space, or the parameterisation with respect to time? If there are any extra constraints beyond "possibly somewhat rushed adiabatic-ish computation", what are those constraints, and why are they considered important to the model? (cont'd)

**(3)** I also don't see why hardware is necessary to describe the comparison with classical simulated annealing. Feel free to assume that you have perfect hardware with arbitrary connectivity: define quantum annealing as you imagine a mathematician might define annealing, free of niggling details; and consider particular realisations of quantum annealing as attempts to approximate the conditions of that pure model, but involving the compromises an engineer is forced to make on account of having to deal with the real world. Is it not possible to make a comparison?

I took your mention of "the quantum gate model" as an invitation to consider theoretical models of quantum computation, in which we list allowed operations. **PostBQP** is the class arising if you suppose that postselection is an allowed operation which has only constant cost. Of course, we can accommodate postselection just by making it part of the conditions we want on the measured output. But we can do the same for classical computation, and no-one seriously suggests that postselection is a technique for efficient classical computation (you can 'solve' **NP**-complete problems that way).

It is apparent that we think about this in different ways, but I'm getting a sense of the implicit theoretical model. I hope you don't mind if I keep trying to tease from you some sort of idea of what QA is in principle. **(4)** Your remark about the initial Hamiltonian is useful, and suggests something very general lurking in the background. Perhaps arbitrary (but efficiently computable, monotone, and first differentiable) schedules are also acceptable in principle, with limitations *only* arising from architectural constraints, and of course also the aim to obtain a useful outcome?

**(5)** Perhaps there is less of a difference between the Hamiltonians in QA and CSA than you suggest. $H_{\mathrm{cl}}$ is clearly obtained from $H_{\mathrm{qm}}$ for $A(t) = 1, B(t) = 0$ if you impose a restriction to standard basis states (which may be benign if $H_{\mathrm{qm}}$ is non-degenerate and diagonal). There's clearly a difference in 'transitions', where QA seems to rely on suggestive intuitions of tunnelling/quasiadiabaticity, but perhaps this can be (or already has been?) made precise by a theoretical comparison of QA to a quantum walk. Is there no work in this direction?

There's a lot going on here; it's a bit difficult to sift through. Note that in your remarks on radix economy, the result that the most economical integer base is ternary is a mathematical result: it's difficult to see what you are getting at when you ask about "what radix to use" for qubits, which would seem to bake in the radix of 2. I also don't see what any of your linked references have to do with the question, with the (possible?) exception of the one on Fibonacci anyons, depending on what exactly you are trying to find out. Could you clarify what precisely you would like to know?

**(6)** One respect in which I suppose the hardware may play an important role --- but which you have not explicitly mentioned yet --- is the role of dissipation to a bath, which I now vaguely remember being relevant to DWAVE. Quoting from Boixo *et al.*: "Unlike adiabatic quantum computing [...] quantum annealing is a positive temperature method involving an open quantum system coupled to a thermal bath." Clearly, what bath coupling one expects in a given system is hardware dependent; but is there no notion of what bath couplings are reasonable to consider for *hypothetical* annealers?

Can you explain why you expect the radix economy to be different in the quantum case? You encode the digits x into $|x\rangle$, so I don't see why it should be different. Or are you thinking of a different representation of the numbers?

Almost all of John's remarks above are essentially an expansion on Definition 3.2 in that article, and some of the discussion in the same Section.

@Rob: Higher dimensions are not necessarily useful. It is more important to have the dynamics that you want, to perform the applications that you want, than to have high dimension. That motivates concerning yourself not with wondering what "the right dimension of qudit to use", but "what systems seem practical to control, and what dimensions of qudits are natural for that system". That is, you put the system *first*, and then ask questions about the qudits *relative* to that choice of system. Doing it in the opposite order is like asking what is the best number of apples.

Is there a solution to this classically, where one might worry that a classical heuristic which stops after some amount of time seems to give good approximate optima up to some input size, and then perform less well in producing approximate optima after some point?

@Rob: In many circumstances it is better to carry more than just apples: it depends on what you want to do with the apples. Even if all you want is apples, what variety of apple also matters, not everyone likes to eat Granny Smith, for example. Sheer number is not what is important --- suitability for a given purpose is a higher consideration. The dimensionality of the qudit is just one factor for that purpose.

I think that this would be due to the small problem instances possessing some structure which is lacking in the general case. For example one might try to understand how well QAOA (Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm) can solve the MaxCut combinatorial optimization problem. One might study MaxCut on small graph instances, but such instances might have lower connectivity or be planar, or possess some other accidental property uncharacteristic of the general problem.
So it would be worth checking whether there are any size "critical points" for typical problems.

@TheEnvironmentalist: that could be considered a *necessary* condition for a quantum advantage, but it isn't sufficient. One also has to be able to see precisely how the structure might be accessible by other means. ('Accessible' here is relative: the HHL algorithm shows aspects of linear algebra which are efficency solvable classically, but even more accessible to quantum algorithms; and Grover's algorithm shows how quantum algorithms seem to obtain *a little bit* more access to information about unstructured problems than classical algorithms can, but 'shine' is a strong word to use there.)

Each physical system has a different "preferred basis", which depends on the system as well as on our capabilities to control the system in said basis. There is no univocal way to say that a basis is better than another in this sense, it all just depends on what do you want to do and what you are capable of doing.

regardless of the validity of the Kalai's arguments, neither D-Wave "quantum computer" nor current proof-of-principle implementations can be used as empirical evidence against them, as fully fault-tolerant computation has not been demonstrated yet. I personally consider the entire discussion about fault tolerant quantum Turing Machines to be something of a red herring, because they are limiting the discussion to the quantum version of a transistor, and then applying that to the entire system. The argument is a red herring and fault tolerant quantum computation is irrelevant in practice when **the answer is easy to check.** This obviously only applies to a certain class of problems (hard to compute, easy to check like discrete logs, factoring, etc) but repeating the computation is common. Intel and AMD processors have frequent errors.

Different machines will consume He at different rates, and I can only roughly estimate. A cryostat for a pulsed EPR machine (which of course is not really quantum computing) consumes in the order of 100L/week (wrong number but approximate order of magnitude). And according to [this document](https://cryocoolerorg.wildapricot.org/resources/Documents/C18/069.pdf), using a liquefier to recover He, 1kWh/L of liquid He is a pretty good yield. So coupling both estimates we could be talking of >1kW of consumption to keep the cryostate cold via reliquified He.

The "more comprehensive explanation" is doing you a disservice, I'm afraid --- it really isn't explaining anything very well. They're completely omitting anything about what makes superpositions different from probability distributions, implying somehow that it is the mere fact that things are being done in superposition that gives an advantage, which is untrue. Your summary reflects this lack of explanation on their part, and describes things which would be equally true of a randomised algorithm.

A rule of thumb: if someone offers you an explanation of quantum computation, but doesn't show you any math behind what it is actually doing, they aren't trying to teach you something: they are trying to *sell* you something.

I'm more used to a description involving the spin energy level structure. In these terms, magnetic molecules such as the one presented by Tejada and Loss have an extremely simple and clean energy level structure (e.g. the Hilbert space consisting of a subset of the 21 levlels of a collective spin S = 10, with the rest of the spectrum being gapped), whereas even small nanoparticles have complicated, more dense spectra. This is why Berkhausen is typically not invoked in those systems to describe the source and influence of magnetic noise, which indeed does happen.

I appreciate the time you're taking to address my questions. We are still misunderstanding each other a bit. You ask "Are arbitrary schedules useful?". I'm confident that the answer is 'no', just as *arbitrary unitary circuits* are not helpful. But while it is not helpful to perform unitary gates willy-nilly, doesn't mean we should define the model to disallow that. While we have some idea of circuits which are not helpful, we don't know precisely which circuits are helpful. So, we define "things which are allowed" generously, and leave 'helpfulness' as a question of design *within* the model.

You say "In principle the field should go from high to low, slow enough to avoid a Landau-Zener transition and fast enough to maintain the quantum effects of qubits." This is the *helpful* thing to do, but you usually don't know just how slow that can or should be, do you? If you don't know precisely what is helpful, and have to accept that finding out just how slow that will be might be a difficult question of design --- where you might be able to do some parts quickly, some more slowly --- just how generous would you be in defining what "an annealing schedule" is?

You may have misunderstood what I was getting at (in a shorthand way) regarding the similarity between the classical and quantum Hamiltonian --- more importantly I'm certain we've talked past each other about the effect of a bath. I thought maybe dissipation to a bath was sometimes considered helpful to how quantum annealers work, when operating in the non-adiabatic regime (as it often will be when working on **NP**-hard problems, because we're interested in obtaining answers to problems despite the eigenvalue gap possibly being very small). Is dissipation not potentially helpful then?

I think that maybe if we can get the confusion about the annealing schedules, and whether or not it the transition has to be along a liner interpolation between two Hamiltonians (as opposed to a more complicated trajectory), it might be helpful to condense the answer to something a bit more concise. The question is rather vague and open-ended. The answer is that Bell states are everything and nothing - you can formulate a quantum computation almost entirely in terms of Bell pairs (see [measurement-based quantum computation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-way_quantum_computer), and some of the ways that a [cluster state can be generated](https://journals.aps.org/pra/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevA.72.056302)), or not use them at all (e.g. [computation by Hamiltonian evolution](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs00220-008-0710-3)), and everything in between.

I think a better way of putting it is that in a regular quantum computer information is stored and manipulated in localized degrees of freedom (like an electron's spin or a photon's polarization); but, in a topological quantum computer it is stored and manipulated in topological degrees of freedom, which are more resistant to noise. These "topological degrees of freedom" can be realized via the braiding of Majoranas. If you want to learn more of the math, I highly recommend the recent survey: [Mathematics of Topological Quantum Computing](https://bit.ly/2EGWnHN). Also, see the above answer.
As I mentioned in a different [answer](https://quantumcomputing.stackexchange.com/a/1627/1813), Gil Kalai gave a talk on [why topological quantum computers cannot work](https://youtu.be/L5gSZsezhoQ).
I think it would be nice if you could expand a little on _how_ they are better at dealing with noise.

I suspect there's some confusion here in the application of the term 'circuit'. The listed components are for an electrical circuit rather than a logical circuit (in the sense implied by a quantum circuit diagram). The classical/quantum correspondence is between a universal set of logic gates for either. Electrical circuits are one way of realizing the standard classical logic gates (but by no means the only one). Similarly, there are many physical means of realizing quantum technologies (which might also include capacitors, inductors etc. see superconducting qubit designs, for instance).

@Discretelizard Any noisy quantum computer can simulate a TQC (assuming they aren't too noisy).
